alt_statements.statement: I think if tech companies are going to use our data, they should have to explain it in simple words kids and parents can both understand, not in tiny confusing writing. They should always ask permission first, tell us exactly what they’re doing with it, and never sell or share it in ways that could hurt us or make us feel unsafe. Since grown‑ups made the internet, they should treat our information like something precious they’re borrowing, not something they own.

I think tech companies should have to explain clearly what data they’re collecting and what they’re doing with it, in words that even kids my age can understand. They shouldn’t be allowed to sell or share our information without asking us (and our parents) first, and they should protect it really carefully so it doesn’t get leaked or misused. If they make money from our data, they should use some of that to make their platforms safer and kinder, not just more addictive or unfair.

As someone who’s worked in healthcare and knows what it means to protect people’s private information, I think tech companies should treat user data like a serious trust, not a commodity to be secretly exploited. At the bare minimum, they should clearly explain what they’re collecting, get real consent (not buried in fine print), and never sell or share sensitive data without strict safeguards. There should also be strong legal accountability when companies misuse data or allow it to be abused—especially for vulnerable people who can’t easily navigate all the digital jargon. If they profit from our data, we should have rights, transparency, and a meaningful say in how that data is used.

As someone who lives a lot of my life online without fancy lawyers or extra protections, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility to be straight up about what data they’re taking, how they’re using it, and who they’re selling it to. If they’re going to make money off our info, there should be strict rules, easy-to-understand controls, and real consequences when they abuse people’s privacy, especially for communities of color that already get targeted and profiled. I don’t think they should be allowed to sell or share sensitive data—like location, health, or financial info—without clear, opt-in consent, and they should have to protect that data like it was their own.

Como alguien que trabaja duro por un sueldo modesto y que no entiende bien el inglés, pienso que las compañías de tecnología tienen la responsabilidad de explicar claramente, en el idioma de la gente, qué datos están recogiendo y para qué los usan. No deberían aprovecharse de nosotros ni vender nuestra información sin un consentimiento sencillo y honesto, y el gobierno debería exigirles reglas estrictas para proteger nuestra privacidad y seguridad.

As someone who works hard to provide for my family and became a U.S. citizen by choice, I think tech companies have a serious responsibility to treat our data with respect, not as something they can just take and sell without being honest about it. If they collect our information, they should clearly explain what they’re doing in plain language, get real consent, protect it like it was their own, and never use it in ways that discriminate or take advantage of people who don’t fully understand what’s happening.

As someone who works in healthcare and sees every day how seriously we treat patient privacy, I believe tech companies should be held to similarly strict standards when handling user data. They should collect only what’s truly necessary, explain clearly and in plain language how that data will be used or sold, and give people meaningful control over opting in or out. There also needs to be real accountability—strong legal consequences—when companies misuse data or fail to protect it, because trust is too important to be treated as just another business asset.

As a medical research scientist, I’m acutely aware of how sensitive data can be and how easily it can be misused, so I believe tech companies have an ethical obligation to treat user data more like protected health information than a free commodity. They should be radically transparent about what they collect, obtain informed and specific consent for how it’s used or monetized, minimize data collection to what’s genuinely necessary, and be held to strict accountability standards—legal and financial—when they fail. From both a scientific and Jewish ethical standpoint, respecting human dignity and preventing harm (pikuach nefesh) should come before profit, which means users must retain meaningful control over their data and the right to opt out without being penalized.

As someone who grew up long before the internet and now sees how much of our lives are tracked, I believe tech companies have a moral duty to treat user data with the same respect and care they’d give to something sacred. They should be completely transparent about what they collect and how they profit from it, get clear consent instead of burying everything in fine print, and never sell or share data in ways that could harm people or manipulate them. With the power they hold, they’re responsible not just to shareholders but to the common good, especially to vulnerable groups like the elderly and the poor.

As someone who works with engineering details every day, I think tech companies should treat user data with the same rigor and safety mindset we apply to aircraft components—no shortcuts, clear standards, and full accountability if something goes wrong. Users deserve to know exactly what’s being collected, how it’s used, and have real control over opting in or out, not buried in fine print. I’m not against companies making money, but monetizing data should never come at the cost of people’s privacy, security, or basic fairness.

As someone who works hard to support my family, I think tech companies have a responsibility to be straight with people about what data they’re collecting and exactly how they’re using it to make money. As someone who works hard to provide for my family, I think tech companies have a duty to treat our data with the same respect I give a customer’s car—only use what’s needed, be honest about what you’re doing, and never cut corners. As someone who’s seen a lot of change over the decades, I think tech companies have a moral duty to treat our data like something sacred, not just a commodity to be squeezed for profit.
